This experience just establishes the fact that PES exams aren't easy. It takes effort to score well and screwing up a single component like the ISA can hurt your final grade. People also tend to underestimate how much effort and practice some courses take to score even a B grade. That's why even scoring an 8.5+ at PES requires a good amount of effort. Also remember that course difficulty and workload increases as you progress through the years, so it's only gonna get tougher.

I'm not saying that people didn't work hard - I'm just stating a fact here that exams at PES aren't easy and are definitely not possible to ace overnight. An overnight study will give you at best a passing grade.

I honestly think PES has gone a bit overboard with the spoon-feeding of course materials. When I started college, all we had was the textbook - no PPTs, no worksheets, no prof's typed out notes, etc. Whatever notes we had was what was written down in class (so a good number of people in class actually wrote notes, because it was needed), so the textbook was essentially mandatory for most courses. I'd say arguably people in my batch went in better prepared because of the book, especially for courses which involved practising problems like EEE, ECE, Civil and Math. Plus it also pushed people to put in more effort.

In my 4th sem or so when PES introduced PPTs we all were pretty happy because it was a welcome change. We did not need to cover page after page from the book for ISAs and the slides made it easier to cover the syllabus in short periods. Then COVID hit and one thing led to another and soon PES started bombarding content in different forms - notes, PPTs, videos, etc.

IMO they really need to roll back a bit on how much they actually provide. Slides and worksheets are ok. There are too many people now who don't even know *which* textbook is prescribed for a course. And some courses like DDCO and OS have absolutely amazing textbooks which explain concepts much better than the profs and their slides. Since you are entering 2nd year now, I would highly recommend picking up the habit of referring to the book. It will greatly help you out. If only people had covered the books, they would have done better.

I honestly have insane respect for people who cross 9.5. Whether a 9.5+ is useful/needed is a separate question altogether but the amount of dedication, consistency and hard work required to cross a 9.5 at PES is extraordinary. The idea is simple but difficult to execute: get a near-perfect score on **every** ISA, project, assignment AND ESA, and then do it for EVERY course. Absolute chads.

Consistent hard work. Ask most 9+ kid and they will tell you that it wasn't the hours of effort before the ESA that helped but rather the little effort they put in throughout the semester from day 1. 

Tbh you don't even need to start from day 1. Do what I did - until 2 weeks before the ISA, just do the bare minimum needed for assignments and projects, but listen in class and make notes. Beyond the classroom, work on your interests, hobbies, projects or impress that person you have a crush on . Do not touch any coursework unless you need a break from your hobbies or you feel the need to study. 

2 weeks before the ISA, cut out everything else. Pay attention in class, make notes, go home and study. Do not do anything else but revise concepts for ISA, cut out all distractions. Avoid the temptation of working on your other interests. When you are studying, study from the source, aka the textbooks, as much as possible, Use the slides for revision (or when the book is unavailable), and cover EVERY resource - book, slides, notes etc. Spend time practicing problems, especially for courses with numericals like stats, AFLL, DDCO etc. 

Try these approaches and see which works for you. I can guarantee you that at least one of them will help you achieve better results.
